snippet: About two-thirds of the city’s recently developed units were found to require occupants to have minimum income levels that were higher than median incomes in the areas.
abstract: Association for Neighborhood and Housing Development report finds that about two-thirds of New York City's affordable housing units require occupants to have higher income levels than the local median income; raises questions about who is benefiting from Bloomberg administration's ambitious plan to build or preserve 165,000 affordable housing units by 2014.
lead_paragraph: About two-thirds of the city’s recently developed units were found to require occupants to have minimum income levels that were higher than median incomes in the areas.

headline.seo: City’s ‘Affordable Housing’ Too Costly for Many, Report Says
headline.main: Some ‘Affordable’ Units Too Costly, Report Says
headline.print_headline: Some ‘Affordable’ Units Too Costly, Report Says

keywords.value: Department of Housing Preservation and Development (NYC)
keywords.name: organizations
